seller_description: Material Stainless Steel Color Silver Finish Type Brushed Brand Secura Item Weight 1.2 Pounds Product Dimensions 11'L x 4.92'W Is Customizable No Manufacturer Secura UPC 638339650261 791507556502 638339651282 Number of Items 1 See less. About this item: Rechargeable Electric Wine Bottle Opener - Easily remove corks in seconds. Compatible with most wine bottle sizes. Open up to 30 bottles on a single charge. Easy to Use - Simply place on top of your wine bottle, press a button, and tada, your wine is open and ready to serve. Small Footprint Saves Space - Our electric wine bottle opener is small enough to store discreetly away when not in use. Keep the charging base next to your wine fridge, storage rack, credenza, etc. Makes an Amazing Present - An elegant color makes our electric wine bottle opener an attractive present, or use it at home, when catering, at banquets, in restaurants or behind the bar. Reliable product and service - 100-240V wide input voltage range covers The known voltages of most places in the world. We offer 12 months and friendly customer service. NOTE: Please charge your wine opener every three months when not in regular use
review: This is the first review I have ever submitted on Amazon but this is the worst wine opener I have ever used! CORK SCREW DOES NOT GO DOWN CENTER OF CORK, IT JUST CHEWS UP THE SIDE! I have had other brands over the years but this one had a lot of good reviews so I thought I would try it. Not every time, but most of the time the cork screw goes off to the side and just chews the cork up and doesn't go down far enough to even pull cork out. Leaves a mess that falls into the wine bottle. Make another choice
expected-output: Alignment of Visual Appearance: The seller's images portray a sleek, stainless steel wine opener with a blue LED light feature, clearly highlighting its stylish and compact design. The buyer's images corroborate this appearance, showcasing the product with the expected aesthetic. The visual alignment is therefore consistent between seller and buyer images. Functional Promises in Description: According to the seller's description, the Secura Wine Opener is advertised to "easily remove corks in seconds" and is designed to be user-friendly with the press of a button. Additionally, it claims compatibility with most wine bottles and offers a compact footprint, along with the capability to open up to 30 bottles on a single charge. The seller emphasizes that it is reliable and ideal for gifting due to its appealing design. Discrepancies in Performance: The buyer review highlights significant functional issues. While they appreciate the product’s visual appeal, they express dissatisfaction with the cork removal process. The primary complaint is that the corkscrew often fails to align properly with the cork center, instead veering off to the side and “chewing up” the cork. This issue appears to lead to incomplete cork removal and, in some cases, causes cork particles to fall into the wine. The buyer describes this as a recurring problem and notes that it results in a messy, frustrating experience, particularly with high-quality wines. This functional shortcoming is a critical deviation from the seller’s promise of “easy cork removal.” Conclusion: Based on the above points, there is a clear discrepancy between the seller’s claims and the buyer’s experience. While the product meets expectations visually, it appears to fall short in terms of performance reliability. The buyer’s dissatisfaction stems from the corkscrew’s inconsistency in centering, which compromises the core function of the product—opening wine bottles effortlessly. This suggests a potential design flaw or quality control issue that detracts from the overall user experience, rendering the product impractical for the buyer’s needs. In summary, while the product’s appearance aligns with expectations, the failure to meet functional promises is the primary source of buyer dissatisfaction. In this case, the fault lies with the seller. While the product meets expectations visually, the buyer's experience reveals a significant functional issue with the corkscrew mechanism. The seller promises easy and reliable cork removal, but the buyer reports that the corkscrew often fails to align properly with the cork, causing it to "chew up" the cork and leave particles in the wine. This issue directly contradicts the seller's functional claims, indicating a possible design flaw or quality control problem. Therefore, the buyer's dissatisfaction is valid, and the seller is at fault for the product not performing as advertised.
label: 0:Here seller is at fault
